title: How will you differentiate the compounds using NMR spectroscopy? - Quora

response.answer_text: Perhaps this question requires some more hands-on explanation. These molecules are acetone and propanal:  As you can see, these molecules seem to be fairly similar. As a matter of fact, they are isomers: the carbonyl group is in the center of the acetone molecule, but is in the end of the propanal molecule. Their 1H-NMR spectra, however, couldn't look any more different:  1H-NMR spectrum of acetone (SDBS No. 319)  1H-NMR of propanal (SDBS No. 2899) The position of the carbonyl group makes a big difference. In the acetone case, the molecule is symmetric and all the hydrogen atoms display the same chemical shift approximately at 2 ppm. In the propanal case, the molecule is not symmetric and the chemical shifts of the methylene and methyl hydrogen atoms will be different. The first noticeable difference is the presence of a very unshielded peak approximately 9.7 ppm, a singlet corresponding to the hydrogen bonded directly to the carbonyl. By shielded I mean “shielded from the magnetic field by the electrons in this particular chemical environment.” At approximately 2.5 ppm one sees a quartet which means that this signal corresponds to a methylene group. The triplet at approximately 1 ppm corresponds to a methyl group. The methylene group is slightly more unshielded than the methyl group because it is directly bonded to the electron withdrawing carbonyl group. As you can see, minimal differences — such as different positions of a carbonyl group — can generate huge differences in NMR spectra.
